top_comment.text:
Hi there -
My name is Cameron Langille. I am a production Intern at The Weather 
Network in Canada. I saw the video Bangkok Vacation Travel Guide. I really 
loved the footage you have of the great city. I was hoping to include it in 
our Top 5 video series. It would be number one of the Top 5 most visited 
city's in the world. So I'm writing you in hopes that I can get permission! 
When you get a moment I'd love to hear from you. Until then take care!

Cheers,
Cameron Langille
Weather Network
Production Intern﻿
top_comment.author: Sheryl Plouffe

comments.text:
+Expedia Thank you for the direct contact. I’ve emailed you!
Sincerely,
Cameron Langille
The Weather Network Canada
Production Intern
comments.author: Sheryl Plouffe

comments.text:
Hi Cameron, thank you so much for watching our Travel Guide! Please refer 
to your YouTube message inbox to continue our discussion. Thanks!
comments.author: Expedia

top_comment.text:
My brother will go to Bangkok on a business trip of the 
work.Enviable.Bangkok is a high temperature city throughout the year.I want 
to pray for the safety of the my brother.﻿
top_comment.author: satoshi sasaki

comments.text:
You only look at video's and think you know Bangkok. Again you've never 
been there, there are a few million tourists per year and hardly does 
something happen there, do you even know how big Bangkok is. I have been 
there. It's better that ignorant people like you don't leave your country. 
You don't even know where I am from. I am from Europe you idiot.
comments.author: raulecruset3

comments.text:
+raulecruset3 i have seen a lot of videos from Bangkok with street 
executions, drugs, guns, rapes, mafia, crack, robberies. Search on google 
and you will find videos with people getting shot in the head on the 
streets of Bangkok. Fuck you and your stupid country . 100 million USD 
you'll have to give me to go there
comments.author: E I N S

comments.text:
+StraightM
That's right, because you never went there you don't know shit. I felt 
really safe in Bangkok, maybe the only thing which is dangerous is the 
traffic. Gang fights are in every capitol city, though it doesn't mean it's 
dangerous. Most of those shooting are on the outskirts in the ghetto.
comments.author: raulecruset3

comments.text:
+chasedoe yeah right! i see a lot of videos from there, news of people 
shooting each other, street executions and shit. i would never go there
comments.author: E I N S

comments.text: It's not that dangerous IMO. He should be fine :)
comments.author: chasedoe

captions.text: Bangkok is situated in central Thailand,
on the Chao Phraya River Delta.

Starting life as a small trading post in the
15th century,

today the Thai capital is home to over 8 million
people,

and is a South East Asian financial and political
powerhouse.

Tropical Bangkok enjoys one of the world's
steamiest climates;

it's also one of the world's hottest travel
destinations.
Judged on criteria like culture, attractions,
cuisine, shopping and value for money,

Bangkok repeatedly wins the highest travel
awards for World's Best City.
Bangkok is a kaleidoscope of contrasts
that charms and assaults the senses simultaneously!

And it's these contrasts, between the old
and the new,

the energetic and the serene, that keeps travelers
coming back.

Bangkok is also known as Krung Thep, the City
of Angels.

First timers confronted with this steamy,
sprawling metropolis,
might wonder where all the angels are.

But they're here,...watch the gentle gestures
of the people,
and you'll begin to understand.
At the cities heart lay it's river and canals.
Climb aboard a long-tail boat

to experience the city from the cool of its
waters.

Then hop off at one of the many temples which
line the river.

One of the most important is Wat Pho, home
of the reclining Buddha.
Be sure to admire the statues feet,

inlaid with 108 mother-of-pearl symbols which
symbolize the Buddha.
Then drop coins into the 108 bronze bowls,
for blessings and good fortune.

The Thai attention to detail you'll see in
the temples,
spills out into Bangkok's daily life.
Each year during the festival of Loi Krathong,

Thai's gather to create incredibly decorative
offerings
for the water spirits.

Releasing these offerings represents the letting
go
of anger and negative thoughts.

Perhaps that's what keeps Bangkok locals so
calm and good natured,

even when the monsoonal waters occasionally
rise!
Thailand is a country of great traditions.

Even the simplest acts are done with skill
and grace,
especially it's culinary arts.
From the 5-star, to the funky,
there are over 50 000 places to eat in Bangkok.
But if you're a foodie in search of paradise,
you'll find it on Bangkok's streets.

Many travelers come to Bangkok just for the
street food
...and it's a bargain!

And while some come to eat, others come to
shop.

At times it seems the entire city is one gigantic
street market.
From fabrics to spices, handicrafts to clothing,
Bangkok is shopaholic heaven.

Central to the Thai mindset is the word, sanuk,
which means fun.

Thai nightlife is legendary. For a great night
out head to Khao San Road.

For over 20 years, Khao San Road has been
a major backpackers' hub;
a great place to pick up vacation tips,

and to party with travelers from all over
the globe.

While Bangkok is a complete destination in
itself,
other treasures lay just beyond the city.
An hours journey to the North,
lays the ancient Thai capital of Ayutthaya.

Rent a bicycle and spend a day exploring the
network of ruins
of this once great city.
For a completely different experience,
head South and explore the nightlife,
in the seaside resort town of Pattaya.
Bangkok is just a short flight away

from some of the world's best beach, island,
jungle
and cultural destinations.
But don't just stop-over or pass through,

do as the angels do, and stay a while - in
Bangkok.
